content.body: Does anyone know of any way to view the most popular NPM packages that depend on a specific NPM package, other than downloading a Gzemnid dataset? (npmjs.com can sort packages by popularity in its name search, and it can list the dependees of a specific package, but it can’t do both at the same time.)
(Use case: Trying to find maximally impactful real-world examples of a library’s usage in the wild.)
* (Use case: Trying to find maximally impactful real-world examples of a library’s usage in the wild, while writing a proposal explainer.)

m.new_content.body: (Use case: Trying to find maximally impactful real-world examples of a library’s usage in the wild, while writing a proposal explainer.)

content.body: Also, I might be confused, but has https://gzemnid.nodejs.org/datasets/ not been updated since 2019?
Hacker News is linking to a new IETF for UUID formats: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-peabody-dispatch-new-uuid-format
Looks pretty neat! UUID v6 perhaps?
(in the meantime, I still find 99% of UUID usages in the wild being v4)
* (in the meantime, I still find 95% or more of UUID usages in the wild being v4)

m.new_content.body: (in the meantime, I still find 95% or more of UUID usages in the wild being v4)

content.body: is "the integral part of _x_", where _x_ is a mathematical value, valid ecma262-speak?
content.formatted_body: is "the integral part of x", where x is a mathematical value, valid ecma262-speak?

content.body: the only instance I can find in the current text is in the prose description of Math.trunc
similarly, there are no references to "the fractional part of _x_"
content.formatted_body: similarly, there are no references to "the fractional part of x"

content.body: ptomato: I think you'd be better off using floor(x) and (x modulo 1), assuming that the semantics for x<0 are what you want.
content.formatted_body: ptomato: I think you'd be better off using floor(x) and (x modulo 1), assuming that the semantics for x<0 are what you want.

content.body: If they're *not* what you want, then you might have to define it, rather than just saying "the integral/fractional part".
content.formatted_body: If they're not what you want, then you might have to define it, rather than just saying "the integral/fractional part".
